solution: Immediately we see that $|\mathbf{P}|=|\mathbf{Q}|=|\mathbf{R}|=1$.  $\mathbf{Q}\cdot\mathbf{R}$ (evaluated both algebraically and geometrically) gives the first identity, and $|\mathbf{Q}\times\mathbf{R}|$ (evaluated similarly) gives the second.  In fact we don't need to use $|\mathbf{P}|$.
statement:
Using the vectors

$$
\begin{split}
\mathbf{P} &= \hat{\mathbf{x}}\cos\theta + \hat{\mathbf{y}}\sin\theta \\
\mathbf{Q} &= \hat{\mathbf{x}}\cos\varphi - \hat{\mathbf{y}}\sin\varphi \\
\mathbf{R} &= \hat{\mathbf{x}}\cos\varphi + \hat{\mathbf{y}}\sin\varphi
\end{split}
$$

prove the familiar trigonometric identities

$$
\begin{split}
\sin(\theta + \varphi) &= \sin\theta \cos\varphi + \cos\theta \sin\varphi \\
\cos(\theta + \varphi) &= \cos\theta \cos\varphi - \sin\theta \sin\varphi
\end{split}
$$
